Award.AwardTitle: UNS: The role of wave dynamics and of tri-leafleted valves in microflows

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511414(Gharib)

This proposal is about understanding the mechanism by which insects breath. This is a project at the interface of microfluidics and bio-inspired fluid dynamics that could lead to the development of pumps for microfluidic networks, like those utilized when one places a miniature laboratory on a computer chip. Both theory and sophisticated experiments are proposed.

The goal is to investigate the bioflow environment around dragonfly nymphs that live underwater and seem to breath by generating a propagating wave through their body and by controlling the flow around their body with motion of their anal valve. The goals are to (1) elucidate the role of the wave in respiratory flow generation, and (2) study how the tri-leafleted anal valve controls the exhalatory and inhalatory flow. It is proposed to simultaneously measure four parameters: the kinematics of the hindgut chamber wall, the kinematics of the anal valve, and the flow inside and outside the chamber. Theory will be developed to describe this process, centered on the movement of internal waves between the tail and the midsection of the dragonfly. Sophisticated experiments involving Synchrotron X-Ray imaging at Argonne National Labs to visualize the internal flow in dragonfly larvae will be performed, while Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) experiments will be conducted to examine the external flow. The nymph's pump can be viewed as a biological zero net mass flux (ZNMF) pump and results from the proposed work could lead to the design of ZNMF pumps with better flow generation and flow control. There are activities designed to reach out to the UCLA Community School, whose students are mostly underprivileged, first-generation college students. The PI will continue the production of research related spots that appear as YouTube videos reaching out to hundreds of thousands of people.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to understand the respiratory and propulsive jet flow generated by a dragonfly larva. A dragonfly larva lives underwater and has a pump system for breathing and propulsion. A control of the jet produced by the system is provided by an active tri-leaflet valve found at the rear end of the pump system. The valve is composed of one top leaflet and two bottom leaflets, each covering roughly one third of the circular jet exit. The individual leaflets are connected to their own retractor muscles that allow independent control. We discovered that the dynamic control of the valve leaflet can bring about changes to the strength and direction of the emerging jet by manipulating the location and the size of the opening.

The location of the opening is controlled by selective retraction of the valve leaflets. We have identified two modes. The dragonfly larvae prefer to open the top leaflet for respiratory jet. Opening the top leaflet, while keeping the bottom two leaflets closed, places the jet opening in off-centered locale. In turn, the emerging jet flows in a diagonal direction. On the other hand, for the propulsion mode, dragonfly larvae partially open all three leaflets to place the opening at the center. The jet emerging from the centered opening flows straight.

The findings help us understand the biological function of the tri-leaflet valve and how it aids the dragonfly larvae’s underwater breathing and propulsion. The secondary flow generated by the deflected respiratory jet showed that jet deflection may be critical for the subsequent refilling of the chamber. The straight jet of the propulsion mode appears to be advantageous for maximum use of the generated thrust. The directional control and their biological implications seen in dragonfly expand our knowledge of how organisms use jet.

Moreover, our findings have broader applications in other science and engineering disciplines that require jet control. As an example, we present their potential use case in advancing the prosthetic heart valve (artificial heart valve used to replace a dis-functional heart valve). The dragonfly larva’s tri-leaflet valve structure is strikingly similar to human heart valve, which motivates us to imagine a new design for a replacement heart valve that can control the direction of the blood flow. The complicated and individually unique morphology of heart and a network of blood vessels demand a careful design of prosthesis, because it may interfere with the patient’s natural blood flow. However, current prosthetic heart valve designs do not allow tailoring for individual’s circulatory system. The direction control shown by dragonfly larvae inspires us to adjust the off-centered opening of the valve as a way of manipulating the jet direction that conform to the natural blood flow of each patient.

In order to apply the off-centered opening concept to different fields, the flow physics behind the jet deflection needs to be understood. For this purpose, we constructed a mechanical model that can produce jet, but with a replaceable jet exit to test various off-centered openings. This experiment confirmed that the asymmetric positioning of the jet opening induces jet deflection up to 9°. Moreover, inside the jet opening, a slowing down of the flow near the unopened area was observed. The decelerating flow increases the pressure, which pushes the fluid upward causing the deflection.

The outcomes of our research was actively disseminated to science community and public. The various parts of our project were presented in academic conferences ranging from entomology to fluid mechanics conferences. Recently, the work was published in a scientific journal. The highlights of the paper were communicated to public through working with our university press. During the award years, the main researcher, Chris Roh, was actively involved in outreach to K-12 schools. He not only communicated the findings of the research at various schools, but he also designed and taught two short courses: bio-inspired engineering and computer programming in research.
